Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Machine Learning and QR

I learned how to build many different types of machine learning models, how to evaluate a given situation or problem and decide which type of model is the best to use. I also gained an appreciation of the mathematical and theoretical underpinnings of these models (which, I've found, is great to have even though you can deploy some of these models without necessarily understanding their inner workings).

Learned a lot of the fundamental data mining and machine learning techniques in pretty good depth. Problem sets are very challenging but doable if you go to office hours and collaborate appropriately with peers. Would recommend.
I learned how to use a variety of skills and techniques in data science and machine learning, the mathematics behinds them, and implementation in R.
I learned the basic theoretical and practical ideas in Machine learning. I also solidified my understanding of theoretical statistics.

I learned what data mining and machine learning was. It really increased my coding skills (in R) and helped me further understand the abilities of computers.  It was my first class working with extremely large databases and it was fun learning how to do that!
I feel like I have a really good understanding of the basic building blocks of machine learning now.
I learned the statistical fundamentals of machine learning methods, and how to comprehensively apply them in the R language.
Definitely learned a lot of really cool machine learning techniques that were applicable to other classes and that in excited to use in the real world.
I learned the intuition behind statistical regressions and machine learning techniques, as well as the math behind them and how to implement them in R on cleaned and examined data sets.
I learned the theory and implementation behind several key machine learning algorithms.
This class was a really good, informative class on machine learning.

I learned both the theory and implementation of several Machine Learning techniques (using R). I worked with messy, real world data sets and really progressed as a data scientist by taking this class.
I learned about the theory and applications of the latest techniques in machine learning, and how to implement some of these methods in R.
I learned a lot from this course. Lafferty is a leading researcher in machine learning, so getting this content was from was a fantastic experience. My R skills also improved a lot.
How to program in R, various types of data analysis methods like regression, classification, text mining, etc

I learned a smattering of different techniques in machine learning, as well as the basics of the R language (and some useful packages). I also learned more about the different trade-offs and challenges of general ML techniques.

Insights gained: 8
Skills gained: 2
Knowledge gained: 14
Learnt a lot about various statistical models, how to use them, and the theory behind them.

Learned a lot in this class. Material was super interesting. All of the info is super applicable to all of the Machine learning going on in the real world right now. Learned different types of machine learning algorithms. Problem sets are long but satisfying once you complete them.
The class provides a great survey of fundamental ML techniques, as well as a great introduction to R and statistics concepts.
I learned R very thoroughly, though I wish there had been a redux on it. I also feel comfortable looking at problems through the lens of data, and what techniques to apply to each kind of problem.
Learnt various machine-learning methods on a conceptual level. Understanding limitations of machine-learning techniques, and bias-variance trade-off.
A good overall knowledge of non-deep learning machine learning methods. You gain proficiency in R and good understanding of the math background of ML.

I learned a lot about various Machine Learning methods from a statistical perspective. More important than any particular machine learning method, I learned how to evaluate different learning models through cross-validation. I also sharpened my R skills and became more familiar with useful packages.

This class is not a good class. You leave lecture without much more than you came in with. Lafferty fails to give anything more than a brief glance at the theory behind the more involved ML methods. Whats more, his notation changes on a slide to slide basis, making it unnecessarily difficult to follow along. The problem sets are terribly organized and untested. Lafferty routinely makes large changes to problem sets after they are posted, often only a day or two before they are due. Yale is supposed to have wonderful professors. Sure, good professors don't always make good teachers, but students expect even bad teachers put time into planning their classes. This CLEARLY is not the case in Laffertys S&DS 365. I learnt what I needed to know for this class by reading the textbook and watching smart 13 year olds explain stuff on YouTube. This is not an exaggeration. I literally watched 13 year olds explain stuff because they do it better than Lafferty does.

tl;dr Lafferty, while a highly credentialed researcher, doesnt seem to care about the quality of his teaching. If you want to learn anything more than the fact that Lafferty wears the same sneakers every day, youve come to the wrong place.

I gained a grasp of the fundamentals of machine learning, from a strong statistical background. I developed my programming skills, particularly in R, and learned a lot about different machine learning methods. I also gained insight into which topics are being pursued in current research.
A good overview of machine learning from a statistical perspective. Pretty comprehensive introduction to traditional methods, and some introduction to modern neural nets etc.

Through this course I developed knowledge regarding the theory behind various techniques in machine learning, such as principal components analysis, random forests, and topic modeling. I also learned how to implement these techniques in the R programming language.
This was a great course on the mathematical framework underlying many important/ recently developed computational-statistical methods.
A ton about all things machine learning
It is a good class.

Some strengths of the course are: clear, engaging lectures; challenging but manageable (and honestly fun) problem sets; and great TAs/ULAs. The only weakness that really comes to mind was the midterm exam -- I didn't like that the midterm tested us on material that, in my experience, wasn't really emphasized in lecture and wasn't covered on prior problem sets.
Lecture was somewhat but not always related to the problem sets. Problem sets were very good. Professor Lafferty was a very interesting lecturer, his passion for the material really came across.

This course was extremely well taught. It was fun, interesting, and I learned so much. Perhaps one of the shortcomings is that the TAs do not have solutions to the pset, and so they often didn't know how to help us, and tended to lead us on wild goose chases.
Prof Lafferty is amazing

I enjoyed the class, but as someone with a stronger math/CS background I found it fairly easy and slow at times. It would be nice if the department offered multiple versions of a course like this that maybe go at different speeds or have varying levels of focus on theory compared to applications.

Strengths: You learn a lot of the math behind the coding and you really get a firm grasp of how to code.

Weaknesses: There weren't enough in class examples of how to code.  Also, the midterm exam was based heavily in theory, which didn't really correlate with your ability to perform the codes on the problem sets.
Professor Lafferty is a really good professor and the subject matter is really interesting, useful and relevant. Parts of the class were a bit disorganized at times.

The strengths are definitely the great content and delivery of the material, the thoroughness and quality of the problem sets, and the attention Prof. Lafferty and the TA's give to the class. Sometimes, the material on the PSETS required extra instruction that we did not receive and had to figure out on our own, but this wasn't a huge hurdle.

Really cool material, but horribly difficult. I pulled all nighters for the 6 psets I completed, and I found it difficult to study for the exam because there was so much material. However, I appreciated the structure of the class, as it didn't have a final exam or project.

The class was incredibly informative and I learned a lot from a legend in the Stats community -- that being said, it was hard to keep up at times, and the course required a lot of Math and learning outside of the classroom.
The material goes by fairly quickly and is quite advanced. However, Psets were structured very well, athough they were very time consuming. You definiteu learn a lot of material.
Great problem sets. I think there could be more feedback for students but overall a great class.

I think that there should be an ethics section of this course or that ethics should be imbedded into lecture routinely. ML is a very powerful field and machine learning techniques are being used to do some really interesting and meaningful work, but there are a lot of ethical questions relating to machine learning and I think there needs to be an open dialogue about those in all iterations of this class. Other than that, a final project might be an interesting way to tie everything together and let students test drive their new skills on data that they're personally interested in.

I can not think of any weaknesses! The biggest strength of the course was most definitely Professor Lafferty- he is a phenomenal teacher and also just a genuinely nice guy. I found most of the problem sets to be the right level of difficulty, so they were challenging but rewarding to complete. Placing the majority of the grade in the assignments really encouraged me to master the material.

The main strength of this course is Professor Lafferty. Hes tremendously knowledgeable, and put a ton of effort into the class. The main weakness was that the psets were often unnecessarily long and tedious. I often felt that I could have mastered the material with half as many problems, or with problem sets thats didnt take 6 hours to run.

The topics themselves are very interesting and the slides are very good. Lafferty is also a very good lecturer who cares about his students. The psets have a fair share of math questions and programming questions which was nice. However some of the problems required a lot of time and computational power to run (like 4 hours for each part) which was a little annoying and made debugging difficult.
I wish the course covered more "modern" developments in ML - we barely talked about Neural Nets until the very end of the class!

The course is well-taught, and covers a nice range of material. I wished that we were shown more of the math/derivations behind the methods; there was a little bit in the HW, but I found those parts much more valuable than other sections, which often were more mechanical (download and use a package, make a plot, etc.) The structure (2 quizzes and a midterm) makes for a much better-balanced semester, although it did mean that there was less incentive to really study the material of the last few classes, given all the other exams/assignments (for other classes) due right around that time. Finally, I felt like using packages in psets was convenient, but not really valuable. It might not be feasible to have us write our own source code for established algorithms, but a write-up in the pset about what the packages were doing, or something like that, would have been valuable. This is nitpicking, but finally, I personally would have loved to spend more time on the less-trivial algorithms, like Newton's algorithm (rather than the brute-force-ish ones, like for building a tree).

Strength: 10
Weakness: 2
Course had a good balance of depth and breadth, and assessments were fair.

Problem Sets were very long. Some questions, for example, would test our knowledge on the same topic but just make things take a long time to do. Overall, great course and really enjoyed the material. Midterm was hard though. Wish we were given a better idea of how to prepare for the exam.

The psets in this class are very well constructed--they are informative and engaging, and tie in well to lectures.

The lectures can be dense: in particular the level of mathematical engagement varied widely from broad/conceptual to high-level proofs. Greater consistency in the level of mathematical derivations would probably help set clearer expectations.
Prof. Lafferty's slides lack clear or consistent notation; most of my comprehension came from watching videos online.
Great overview of many techniques. Not sure how to get us to grapple more with the implications/interpretations of various techniques, but would have been useful. Perhaps a final project.
I think there should be more intuitive explanations on the math basis of the methods. Sometimes we just skim through the math explanation.

This class was phenomenal. There is very little I would do to change the course. Never in my four years at Yale have I found myself actively participating in a majority of the lectures until I took this class (and this says a lot because it was a 9:00 AM course) . The assignments were on the long side, but they were really cool and in the last assignment, we implemented a machine learning to solve word analogies (i.e A is to B as C is _____).  Professor Lafferty is a very clear and inspiring lecturer, and he leaves ample time in class for questions. One suggestion I have is to rethink the prerequisites. Unfortunately, I think a lot of students struggled in this class and didn't get to enjoy it as much as I had. I think S&DS 242 was officially a prerequisite, but my sense is that many students who hadn't taken S&DS 242 were still encouraged to take the class. From my observation, these students struggled which is a shame because they would have enjoyed the class had they waited another year and taken the proper prerequisites.

This class is not a good class. You leave lecture without much more than you came in with. Lafferty fails to give anything more than a brief glance at the theory behind the more involved ML methods. Whats more, his notation changes on a slide to slide basis, making it unnecessarily difficult to follow along. The problem sets are terribly organized and untested. Lafferty routinely makes large changes to problem sets after they are posted, often only a day or two before they are due. Yale is supposed to have wonderful professors. Sure, good professors don't always make good teachers, but students expect even bad teachers put time into planning their classes. This CLEARLY is not the case in Laffertys S&DS 365. I learnt what I needed to know for this class by reading the textbook and watching smart 13 year olds explain stuff on YouTube. This is not an exaggeration. I literally watched 13 year olds explain stuff because they do it better than Lafferty does.

tl;dr Lafferty, while a highly credentialed researcher, doesnt seem to care about the quality of his teaching. If you want to learn anything more than the fact that Lafferty wears the same sneakers every day, youve come to the wrong place.

The lectures were great and the assignments really made us learn the methods we discussed in class. Professor Lafferty himself is the strength of the course, in my opinion, because he offers really good insights into the subject matter and explains it well. In terms of improvement, I think the assignments were a bit too long and involved too much R coding that wasn't guided. Some of the most challenging parts of the assignments were just getting the non-machine learning code to work, which wasn't very enlightening. This started changing toward the end of the semester, so maybe this feedback is already being addressed.

I thought the course focused too much on math (especially the lectures) although I liked that the assignments and tests focused more on intuition. 

I'd re-structure this course to be more CS-focused (PYTHON >> R) and practical -- have us do a real final project using Keras / Tensorflow and get a taste of modern ML.

The interesting and topical nature of the material was one large strength of the course. The problem sets were also generally engaging and interesting to think through and solve. However, the organization and grading of the course negatively impacted my learning and overall experience of this class. One major issue was a clear disconnect between the professor and the teaching fellows, and an even larger gap between the professor and the ULAs. There were often typos or mistakes in the assignments that made the problem sets much more difficult, and that required updated instructions or advice from the instructors. In addition, there was very little useful feedback provided on the problem sets, and no solutions were ever posted that would have allowed students to see how their code could have been improved.

Overall this course was great. The problem sets were well designed, but I wish there had been more guidance on using R. I also think it would have been more interesting and helpful to have students more often write simplified implementations of the statistical methods gone over in class (rather than just implementing already-developed packages).

This class had the best-planned syllabus I've ever encountered. I very much appreciated this, especially since so many syllabi are terrible and make classes unnecessarily difficult and stressful. Problem sets were every 1.5 weeks, but never due on the same day as an exam. Office hours were scheduled well, though the ULAs often were not able to help, since the class covered more material than in previous semesters. Lectures were always engaging.

The quizzes were so short and tested such a small portion of what had been taught that they really came down to luck in which slides you looked over most recently. If they continue to be that short, there should be more, maybe every week but covering less material.

One p-set was dropped, and there was no final exam or project, which I think was good because p-sets were challenging and we learned the material thoroughly by completing them.

I WISH THERE HAD BEEN AN OPTION TO PROGRAM USING PYTHON INSTEAD OF R.
Learned a lot.  Grading was a little randomr as all grades on psets were high and we only had 1 midterm that was a little random.
yes!

Yes! It's an interesting and well-taught course. Great introduction to the world of machine learning, so if that's an area of technology that you're interested in knowing about (or maybe working in), this is a great place to start!

I would recommend for anyone looking for a relatively intensive introduction to machine learning and data mining techniques. You don't need to know STAT 242; I had 238 and was fine. You need to review some linear algebra in order to understand a lot of the lectures.
Yes! The material is so interesting, and useful. It's super thought provoking and engaging, even if it is a lot of work.
Yea

This is a great course to take, especially with Professor Lafferty. The problem sets do a great job of reinforcing the concepts that are taught in class and you gain a good basic understanding of machine learning concepts.

A decent introduction to machine learning. Coming in with a strong math and CS background the course was pretty easy and not much work. That said, without that background it would require you to teach yourself some things along the way.

I would recommend this course to another student.  I would however also suggest that you start the problem sets as early as possible and go to the office hours, because they aren't that prompt on Piazza. Also, the earlier in the week you go to office hours, the less crowded they are, and you can get good one on one attention which is super helpful.  In terms of the midterm, really go through the slides and study them.  Attending lecture and paying attention to what Prof Lafferty says is a must to understanding the theory behind all of the methods.
Yes! This class will give you a great foundation in machine learning. Be sure to be really on top of self studying for statistics if you dont have a large background in the subject.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone that want's to really understand modern machine learning and it's foundations. Although this course is statistical and mathematical in nature, the problem sets are very applied and you get to work with real data and programming. Overall a great course.
Yes, if this course was their main difficult class of the semester. The material was super interesting, but it was just so hard and time consuming.

I would highly recommend to anyone who feels like they need to learn about the field, with the caveat that you should be well-versed in Linear Algebra, Stats, and be prepared to grind on a class. Preferably take the class with friends.
If you are in the S&DS major, definitely take this course.
Best class I have taken at Yale! If you take this class, take it with Lafferty! He is a god. Very interesting material and great p-sets.

I would recommend this course to any student looking for a solid introduction of different machine learning techniques. I think this class will be most meaningful if students have a solid math background (linear algebra, probability theory, statistical theory) and have some computing experience (in R would be ideal), but anyone willing to put in the work to really delve deeply into the theory would also probably be fine. The class is a lot of work and some of the concepts can be very difficult to understand, but this has been the best class I've taken at Yale so far, so all of the work was completely worth it.

I would absolutely recommend this course, especially with John Lafferty. The theory he covers in lectures can be a little dense and difficult at times, but he dedicates a good amount of time to talking about some really interesting applications. The problem sets were generally challenging, but not excessively so, and I liked that they focused primarily on implementing things in R rather than proving formulas. The heavy weighting of the problem sets was pretty nice too, because it encouraged me to really understand the material (and it meant that the midterm and quizzes were relatively low-stakes). If you can take it with JL, do it- he is at the top of his field.
Definitely. If Professor Lafferty is teaching it, prepare to spend a lot of time on the problem sets.
It's a good class, take it with Prof Lafferty! Hope that the TAs would be more knowledgeable next year though.
No, not with the course content structured as it is.

I think I would recommend this course to another student, because it's well-taught, well-organized, and covers a lot of relevant material. The workload also is not too bad. The problem sets can be tedious, and the material isn't always as mind-blowing as you might expect (of course, a lot of it is very cool, but it can also occasionally be a little repetitive or simple). But if you have a pre-existing desire to learn about ML, it is certainly worth taking.

Hell
yeah
you should totally
take this course
lots of machine learning involved; you'd be surprised at how much linear regression is involved. knowing
the fundamentals really helps
there's no BS involved
cool structures like regression trees
what more can i tell ya/

This course gives a broad overview of the techniques being used in machine learning today. The material spans from basic linear and logistic regressions, to tree-based methods, to image recognition and topic modeling. Lectures feature substantial mathematical theory behind the concepts, but the problem sets are mostly applied and really help you understand how each method is implemented. Professor Lafferty is good at explaining concepts in addition to theory, and is very willing to answer questions after class. Overall, it is a tough class (get started on the problem sets early) but the problem sets are interesting and doable (and account for most of the grade) and you learn to understand and apply many important topics.

Machine Learning was a very rigorous class that required spending many hours on the problem sets, which had both theoretical math questions and practical coding parts in R. The class will give you a good grounding in traditional machine learning techniques, such as regressions and trees, and it includes practical considerations such as cleaning data and choosing variables.
This class provides good exposure to various models used in statistics and machine learning, and Lafferty ensures a solid understanding of the underlying theory. Would recommend.

Yes definitely. The class does take a long time and can be stressful at times, but the material was definitely interesting. Lecture slides are really good and Lafferty is an amazing professor. Exams are hard though.
If you're interested in or curious about ML, this is a good class to take. It helps ground some of the realities, and gives you practice at handling interesting data sets.
I would recommend this course when it's being taught by a different professor.
Yes, this course has become very math heavy, and good stat background in expected for the course.

If you have the prereqs, and Lafferty is teaching it, absolutely take this course! The lectures are fantastic and easy to follow, the material is so cool, and you get to work on fun problems on the assignments. One example of a fun homework problem is that we implemented a machine learning algorithm to find embeddings of different music artists projected into a 2-dimensional space (this is called t-SNE) and then we could play with plotting the artists in the 2-d space to see who was similar to who. Once I submitted the assignment, I could have spent hours just playing around with the output to see whether certain pairs of artists are given similar embeddings. The lectures were also engaging.  Never in my four years at Yale have I found myself actively participating in a majority of the lectures until I took this class (and this says a lot because it was a 9:00 AM course). I was well prepared to take the course, so I really enjoyed it, but I am not sure if students without the prerequisites enjoyed it

This class is not a good class. You leave lecture without much more than you came in with. Lafferty fails to give anything more than a brief glance at the theory behind the more involved ML methods. Whats more, his notation changes on a slide to slide basis, making it unnecessarily difficult to follow along. The problem sets are terribly organized and untested. Lafferty routinely makes large changes to problem sets after they are posted, often only a day or two before they are due. Yale is supposed to have wonderful professors. Sure, good professors don't always make good teachers, but students expect even bad teachers put time into planning their classes. This CLEARLY is not the case in Laffertys S&DS 365. I learnt what I needed to know for this class by reading the textbook and watching smart 13 year olds explain stuff on YouTube. This is not an exaggeration. I literally watched 13 year olds explain stuff because they do it better than Lafferty does.

tl;dr Lafferty, while a highly credentialed researcher, doesnt seem to care about the quality of his teaching. If you want to learn anything more than the fact that Lafferty wears the same sneakers every day, youve come to the wrong place.

Yes, but only if you are interested and if you have some programming background. I would recommend an intro stat course with some R as the basic requirement. Otherwise, it is challenging but very interesting, and very much worth it, since machine learning is becoming more and more of an important tool in many research areas.

A good introduction to ML from the statistical side -- this course focuses on the mathematical foundations and classical methods of machine learning. It's a good classic course, and Lafferty is a good professor but you won't be learning the stuff of the ML hype (conv nets, LSTMs and whatnot). R is a real pain. Overall pretty easy A given the emphasis on homeworks.

As this was the first year this course was offered, there were numerous hiccups and issues. However, the material is interesting and Professor Lafferty is a competent lecturer. If you are interested in machine learning, there are not many other classes (as far as I know at least) that cover this material, so this might be your best bet. If the issues that existed this year, such as errors on the problem sets and issues with the grading/feedback system, are resolved, I would recommend this class.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning more about the forefront of statistical-computational methods.

Definitely recommend if Professor Lafferty is teaching it. He is a father of the field and has so much knowledge to share. The topics were wide-ranging and interesting. Much less theory and more practical applications and coding than other statistics classes have, which was a nice change of pace.

Some of the problem sets had kinks which should be worked out by the next time the class is taught. Namely, they were designed for Python but had to be implemented in R, so a lot of them took far too long to run (longer than was practical in any sense), but the TAs just didn't know because they hadn't tried to run it.
Yes learned a ton!
